The good news is that there are hundreds of thousands of people across America who want that future. Lots of them are actively working for it now and tons more would launch their own efforts if they had support to do it

Eee, nerve damage is so rough! I'm looking forward to being able to bike again though I do think if I had a recumbent bike I could use it. Would definitely want protected bike lanes if I were to be biking lower to the ground though!

And there are a LOT more impairments and age restrictions that stop a person from driving than would stop a person from rolling or walking a mile. Increase the amount of places a person can get to on their own and you increase mobility liberation!

"If you have come here to help me you are wasting your time, but if you have come because your liberation is bound up with mine, then let us work together" is always true but super true when it comes to disability justice
Also if you aren't disabled or mobility impaired currently, at some time in your life you probably will be for at least a bit! Unless you die suddenly.

When confronting conspiracy theory-type thinking, I find it useful to remember that conspiracy theories help people make sense of the world (and protect their feelings). Here's a brief(ish) look at dealing with conspiracy theories in your advocacy work open.substack.com/pub/carterla....

I know I keep saying this, but as urbanists we need to make sure that we're aligning ourselves with disability activists as much as possible. It's the right thing to do and it benefits everyone. 

NYC this is a joke. #accessiblecities
Thanks!
💯 but also, sometimes it's just not the time/place to engage. It's tricky!

Yeeeeeeep. It's a big part of why I set up my business of training people to be more effective advocates. People want change but stuff can be complicated and daunting so it's tempting to just walk away from it all. Helping people build the skills they need to be empowered vs following conspiracies

Don't overpromise the impact of the action. "Yeah, your one call to the Governor won't make a difference, but I'm doing XYZ to get 100,000 other people to make the call too. So I need you to make that call now and anything you can do to help get others to make the call to helps get us noticed"

I've had to bring people away from conspiratorial thinking and into taking meaningful political action, I've found that it takes building interpersonal trust, having a big conversation where you lay out a full picture and answer their questions and "what abouts," provide them w/ an action AND...

It is, but it's can also be really painful to know things. Knowing that the world could actually be better can be incredibly painful-- especially if a person doesn't know what work is needed & what they can do to make it better. Much easier to think of themselves as powerless

And instead of feeling bad for not taking meaningful action to address the real problem, they get to feel smarter than you-- since they can say you're just a pawn who is wasting your effort getting petition signers etc

Folks can experience a sort of "cosmic horror" when they become aware of the deep complexities of politics & reality all around them and their role in it (car deaths, climate change, etc) and conspiracy theories help give them an alternative way to make sense of everything

So to someone who doesn't think about the damage their car does to them and the world, the push for "walkable cities" seems like some outsider trying to force them to change how they live their life for no good reason. The conspiracy theory fills the gap by providing a simple reason

Conspiracy theories help people make sense of the world. They're attractive to people who see there are forces at play in the world which they don't understand. They are particularly appealing to people who feel powerless but don't want to do the actual work since it justifies their inaction.

Here for it but I think it might be too shallow? Tubing on Lake Merritt could be amazing though
100% fixable. Lots of little low cost improvements like that are gonna help increase ridership (and we should also fund the bus a bunch more!)
Right? The stop is right after the bus turns a corner so maybe those spot locations are hard for visibility?
Yeah I've only been skipped once or twice. Posted this while on the bus and saw it skip a senior in a wheelchair who was waving 😢

Every time a bus is late, people lose a little trust in it. And I think that trust goes down a lot further than when a train is late. I expect buses to always be running a bit late-- and maybe that's me. Signs at bus stops showing where the next bus is would do wonders for trust imo

Taking the bus today,  thinking about trust- how it can be built and kept. Can you trust that the bus will come on time? That it will come at all? Can you trust that it'll actually see & stop for you? 
I think bulb outs help fix the will they see & stop for you. Interested in your thoughts!

Adding benches & shelters to bus stops increases ridership by 80%. Adding a real-time display of when the next bus arrives triples it. States and climate foundations should give grants for bus stop improvements

Yes! It's extremely important when doing your bike advocacy work to reach out to local groups working on disability justice issues to engage with them. They are wonderful potential allies

Reducing space for cars is often equated with reducing access for people with disabilities.

This is not only false, it prevents cities from creating enabling environments; where those who can't drive can still move safely, conveniently, and autonomously.
I wonder what the venn diagram is of people who drive two blocks when walking is safe, and within their physical abilities...and people who meticulously recycle or some other eco-action.

Yeeeep, those are tricky ones to shift. I think events around creating walk/bike/transit joy are helpful to get people to shift more ingrained habits like that. And yeah, probably a touch more of "personal responsibility" language might help shift those small choices too when doable.

From my experience people HATE even considering that something they are doing is harmful. They are much more open to a (true) narrative in which the infrastructure choices by others have forced them into car dependency. It's not their fault they drive, and together we can change the infrastructure

Yes! I think a key part to helping people be open to the reality that their driving habits are likely their largest source of emissions is pointing them to local structural changes that'd give them & others more mobility options
The more people you can get to sign the petition here the better our chances are if getting the protected lane! https://actionnetwork.org/petitions/a-safer-better-grand-avenue-at-lake-merritt
Excellent! My email is on my website - www.carterlavin.com send me some schedule options and a bit about what you'd like to work on and we'll find a time! Looking forward to it

In case any of my fellow North Americans need to hear this today: You can change your community for the better, even in the face of opposition.

It takes work but that work can be easier and more enjoyable if you know how to do it effectively.

September is Bay Area Transit Month where individuals, orgs and agencies put on all sorts of transit-themed events. I'm working on a handful including one about cars and the prison system.

If you're interested in putting on an event, let me know and I can plug you in to some volunteers

And if those folks want helping learning how to more effectively fight for the bike and transit changes they want in their community, I am here to help

Yes! Street vending is a sign of a healthy city. Cities should also help make it easier for these informal economy businesses to join the formal economy to increase tax revenue too

Fire in downtown Oakland? Looks like it's near Old Oakland. Anyone know what's up?

Yes! Moving is expensive, difficult and often illegal! Plus slowing climate change requires that we win changes to make North American communities easier places to be car-free.

When you are alone in calling for a rail extension, bus service improvement, or protected bike lane, you are easy to ignore. Build a coalition & you're more likely to win. Here's a free training on how to do that  https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZckc-GgpjMoH90Tb7bPbnWF_kwx5u4L8dhL
So would a person have to sue the city for not enforcing ADA on car encroachment of sidewalks?
It's important for advocates to remember that most people don't want to be agitated! But they're more open to being informed & empowered.
Pointing out an absence is always good especially if you couple it with pointing out a cause, solution and an action they can take. Otherwise it's just viewed as agitation that they'd rather ignore
I just got on BlueSky and yeah- great seeing so many other transit/bike/urbanist folks out here! Giving up isn't an option- the good news is we can always fight better

In certain ways, transit, bike and anti-traffic violence advocacy is a lot easier than advocacy on other issues.
https://carterlavin.substack.com/p/the-secret-weapon-of-transit-bike?sd=pf

You can win safer streets, better bike lanes, and better transit for your community. You have to fight for it though and get lots of folks in your community on your side. It can be hard, but it's a winnable battle. One of the best ways to win it is talking with strangers face-to-face
Yes and in the meantime regulators need to step up enforcement and lawmakers need to step up their funding of inspection & enforcement
That's a classic conundrum for transit advocates! Yay for full trains but a little extra space is always nice 😜

This is a great political organizing opportunity too since more people= more voters. But we all have to do the work of getting fellow transit & bike riders to speak out and demand the road space we deserve.
